awd_titl_txt: CAREER: On Mutualism of Modularity and Concurrency Goals
awd_abstract_narration: This project focuses on the problem of making concurrent programs easier to write correctly and to implement efficiently.  Modularity promotes ease of understand and maintainability, but modularity is often at odds with the discovery and exploitation of concurrency needed to get high performance while avoiding undesirable interactions and race conditions. To approach this problem, this project is developing a novel language, Panini, in which events are first-class objects which can be analyzed to plan concurrent executions.  The objective is to reconcile modularity and concurrency goals so that modular designs are naturally more amenable to concurrency. Panini will be evaluated in terms of its ability to support program modularity and performance on publicly available versions of large open-source software projects on multi-core processors use. The broader impacts are to make software more reliable, maintainable, and at the same time faster. Considering that software systems are essential elements of today's society, better and faster software will directly impact society.

por.por_cntn:
Decreasing complexity of software is vital to make it better, increasing concurrency is important to make it faster. This project focused on the problem of making concurrent programs easier to write correctly and to implement efficiently. Modularity promotes ease of understand and maintainability, but modularity is often at odds with the discovery and exploitation of concurrency needed to get high performance while avoiding undesirable interactions and race conditions. To approach this problem, the project developed a novel language, Panini, in which events are first-class objects which can be analyzed to plan concurrent executions. The objective was to reconcile modularity and concurrency goals so that modular designs are naturally more amenable to concurrency. The transformative approach of thinking about software design that this project has explored has the potential to balance these goals, and to make software more reliable, maintainable, and at the same time faster. Considering that software systems are essential elements of today's society, better and faster software will directly impact society. Panini was evaluated in terms of its ability to support program modularity and performance on publicly available versions of large open-source software projects on multi-core processors use. The project has also made contributions to the advanced cyberinfrastructure. Panini-related tools were disseminated to the general public via open source tools freely available to the society. The project also contributed to the research-based training of five doctoral and two masters students who are contributing to the US information technology workforce as well as academic institutions. The project also contributed to research-based training of over a dozen undergraduate students who participated in projects funded by REU supplements. The broader impacts were to make software more reliable, maintainable, and at the same time faster. Considering that software systems are essential elements of today's society, better and faster software will directly impact society.
